bunpro.writeup: In Japanese, two副詞(adverbs) that are used to express very similar ideas areちゃんと, and きちんと. These words may be used either at the beginning of a sentence (to modify the meaning of the whole sentence), or before verbs.ちゃんとandきちんとboth translate quite closely to 'properly', or 'neatly'.Fun FactHistorically,ちゃんとwas also used to convey 'quickly'. However, it is almost never used for this purpose in modern Japanese. Despite this, bothちゃんとandきちんとdo have a slight nuance of doing something 'without dawdling'. This can mostly be attributed to the base meaning of 'properly' also implying that something is not done lazily.

examples.english: Did you properly do your homework?

examples.japanese: ちゃんと野菜も食べなさい！
今度からはもっとちゃんとした車を買おう。
examples.english: From now on, I should buy a proper car. (From now on, I'm not going to cheap out on a car)

examples.japanese: 結婚式にはきちんとした服装で来てください。
examples.english: Please come to the wedding dressed properly.

examples.japanese: 社長が来たぞ。ちゃんと立て。
examples.english: The CEO is here. Stand up, quick! (Stand up now, quickly, don't slouch)

examples.japanese: 遊びに行く前にきちんと部屋の掃除をしなさい。
examples.english: You have to clean your room properly before you go out and play.

examples.japanese: 母親は子供に言う：「お祖母さんが来る前に部屋をきちんと片付けしなさい！」
examples.english: Mother speaking to her child: 'Clean your room properly before grandma comes!'

examples.japanese: 優しい次長：「昼休みなんだからちゃんと休んでね。」部下：「はい! わかりました、次長！」
examples.english: Gentle vice-director: 'It's lunch, so take a proper break.'Subordinate: 'Yes! Understood, vice-director!'

examples.japanese: 親が子供に聞く：「ちゃんと宿題したの?」
examples.english: A parent is asking a child: 'Have you properly done your homework?'

examples.japanese: アルバイトの面接：「独りで暮らせるように、何かちゃんとした仕事を見つけたいのです。」
examples.english: Part-time job interview: 'I want to find a proper job so that I can live by myself.' (decent)

examples.japanese: 書き方について教師が学生に言う：「この言葉読みにくいね。もっときちんと書きましょう。」
examples.english: A teacher speaks to a student about the way of writing: 'This word is hard to read. Let's write it more neatly (properly).'
